captions.text:
I&#39;ve done so many fucking Assassin&#39;s Creed 
games in my career to date, I worry I&#39;ve used

every imaginable angle for a snarky intro. I could 
take the piss out of the hackneyed subtitling—ooh,

Shadows now, is it? Bet that brainstorming 
session got through a whole Kellogg&#39;s variety

pack—but that in itself would be hackneyed 
at this point. I&#39;ve been doing that since

Assassin&#39;s Creed Revelations. What am I, the 
subjectively subpar subtitle subcommittee? I

say all of this as a sort of preemptive 
apology for the following opening gag.

Assassin&#39;s Creed Shadows? More like Assassin&#39;s 
Creed Badows. ...Well, no one else is bringing

their A game. Assassin&#39;s Creed Shithouse 
is an Assassin&#39;s Creed set in feudal Japan,

meaning the franchise can now realize its destiny 
of being about actual ninjas rather than ninja

pirates. Or ninja Vikings. Or ninja... sex 
pests? We open playing as Yasuke—famous

historical black Samurai, bodyguard to 
Oda Nobunaga, and rampaging brick wall

on legs—as he goes Godzilla-mode on a village of 
shinobis over the course of the combat tutorial.

We then switch to controlling Naoe, a villager 
trained as a ninja assassin by her dad who

keeps saying he doesn&#39;t want her to be a 
ninja assassin; I guess he assumed she&#39;d

use the shuriken skills to be really good at 
distributing Danish pastries or something,

and who tells her to go fetch the box 
with the MacGuffin in it. Which she does,

going through a second combat tutorial in the 
process, but then the box is stolen and her

father murdered by the usual secret faction 
of masked baddies. As in, all of them. They

literally line up in costumes like they&#39;re posing 
for the school photo just to kill this one dude

in front of his daughter. That was the first 
major eye roll moment for me. I mean, these

are all powerful behind the scenes manipulators. 
Can you imagine what a nightmare it must have been

to coordinate schedules for this? Just to stand 
there mostly not joining in the killing? Sorry,

I can only make Sunday evening; I&#39;m oppressing 
the proletariat all afternoon. Anyway,

Naoe is left for dead and flashes back to her 
ninja training for no real reason except for the

sake of having a third combat tutorial and then 
wakes up being nursed back to health by kindly

strangers and has to relearn her skills. And guess 
what that means? Combat tutorial number four.

I&#39;m getting the sense you&#39;re worried I&#39;m not 
paying attention, game, perhaps justifiably,

because by this point, I was yelling &quot;GET ON WITH 
IT&quot; over all the dialogue. The game proper starts,

and a couple of targets into the hit list, a 
famous historical bastard comes to Naoe and says,

&quot;Oda Nobunaga is the leader of the masked 
baddies, go kill him.&quot; And I was like, &quot;Okay,

well, it&#39;s far too early to resolve the main plot, 
so thanks for the tip, obvious twist villain.&quot;

Naoe&#39;s attempt to kill Nobunaga is foiled by 
Yasuke, who&#39;s about to kill her but then he sees

her hidden blade and goes, &quot;Oh shit, I can&#39;t kill 
her, she&#39;s the protagonist.&quot; And Nobunaga goes,

&quot;Oh, bloody hell. Well, I&#39;m out of ideas. Seppuku 
time.&quot; Then Yasuke turns to Naoe and goes, &quot;Hey,

I need a purpose in life, so yours&#39;ll do. 
Please don&#39;t murder me as well even though

I killed all your mates.&quot; &quot;Eh, who am I to 
judge?&quot; The hoops this plot jumps through

to set itself up, it only really makes sense 
if you assume every character already knows,

instinctively, who the protagonists of the 
story are. Otherwise, Yasuke just seems

to pledge lifelong service to whoever he was 
standing closest to when Nobunaga died. Good

thing he wasn&#39;t at the ice cream van; he&#39;d have 
become the first sworn sword of Mister Whippy.

From then on, we can switch back and forth between 
Naoe and Yasuke in a sort of exaggerated version

of the Assassin&#39;s Creed Syndicate dichotomy: 
the tiny, willowy, sneaky lady or the fucking

rampaging side of beef in a silly hat. But having 
just spent three hours and four combat tutorials

exclusively playing as Naoe the ninja assassin, 
my first question was, &quot;Why would I want to now

play as Yasuke, huge, lumbering warrior resembling 
the result of the forbidden love affair between

unstoppable force and immovable object?&quot; 
&quot;So you can choose between the stealthy or

the combat-based experience, Yahtz.&quot; But who the 
fuck buys a game called Assassin&#39;s Creed Shadows

and doesn&#39;t want to play as the stealthy ninja 
assassin? It&#39;s not called Clumsy Murderer&#39;s Creed

Standing Around Being Obvious Like A Bipedal 
Carthorse. Maybe we&#39;re supposed to decide

which character we find more compelling as a 
protagonist, but that&#39;s like comparing damp tissue

paper to moist kitchen roll. Neither Mr. &quot;pledges 
lifelong allegiance to whoever spoke to him last&quot;

nor little miss &quot;your training is complete young 
one; avenge my death&quot; stock kung fu movie revenge

plot particularly move the needle, the needle in 
this metaphor representing my intrigued erection.

&quot;Well, what were you expecting, Yahtz?&quot; This. 
Frankly. It&#39;s not what I was HOPING for,

but it&#39;s what I was expecting. I was HOPING 
Ubisoft had learned not to make bland,

futile attempts to simultaneously appeal to 
everyone and their cat and their other extremely

angry cat that likes mindless brute-force combat. 
Shadows is a full-throated Jiminy Cockthroat. How

my needle drooped as I was obliged to craft gear 
upgrades and do collectible scavenger hunts and

when I saw the levelling system was back, forcing 
me to go through the missions in strictly linear

ascending order of difficulty, thus removing all 
purpose for the needlessly oversized open world

except that it means we have to ride through 
samey terrain for half an hour to fucking get

anywhere until we&#39;ve hypnotized ourselves into 
wanting to buy a shrubbery. At around level 20,

I started getting underlevelled for the 
critical path and had to grind up with

contract missions that were all exactly 
the bloody same: go to a copy-pasted

enemy campground and go Jason Voorhees on the 
place. It was either that or put up with my

assassin blade only assassinating people halfway, 
necessitating an immediate shift to the annoying,

mashy combat or going through the rigmarole of 
running around a corner, squatting in a bush,

and waiting 30 seconds for the dozy 
pillock to entirely forget my existence,

dismissing the spurting wound in his throat as 
the work of an unusually ambitious mosquito.

I&#39;ve repeatedly said that Ghost of Tsushima 
was indistinguishable from an Assassin&#39;s

Creed game set in feudal Japan. I need to 
correct myself. Turns out, side by side,

I can very easily tell Ghost of Tsushima from 
the Ubisoft original. Because Assassin&#39;s Creed

is the one that&#39;s really fucking boring. Ghost of 
Tsushima is the one with the nice visual design

and fun ideas like using the wind as a direction 
indicator; AssCreed is the one where everything&#39;s

murky and indistinct and we have to hammer Eagle 
Vision like it&#39;s the fucking restart button in

Hotline Miami to differentiate the important 
gameplay elements from the four hundredweight

of useless details that some poor sod at Ubisoft 
had to miss the birth of their child to finish

polishing up and which the game&#39;s own interface 
is now directing me to completely ignore. I can&#39;t

think of a single moment or gameplay element 
in Shadows that might enable it to stand out

in memory. With the possible exception of making 
Yasuke jump into a haystack and watching him do

his back in, lol. All in all, it&#39;s yet another 
indication that the triple-A industry needs to

hurry up and collapse. I want to move on to the 
time where we call it triple-A not because of

the budget but because that was the sound 
it made as it fell off the fucking cliff.
